00045 
00046 /*
00047 *------------------------------------------------------------------------
00048 *                               Bidiagonalization
00049 */
00050 /*
00051 *                       Left Hausholder Transformations
00052 *
00053 * Zero out an entire subdiagonal of the i-th column of A and compute the
00054 * modified A[i,i] by multiplication (UP' * A) with a matrix UP'
00055 *   (1)  UP' = E - UPi * UPi' / beta
00056 *
00057 * where a column-vector UPi is as follows
00058 *   (2)  UPi = [ (i-1) zeros, A[i,i] + Norm, vector A[i+1:M,i] ]
00059 * where beta = UPi' * A[,i] and Norm is the norm of a vector A[i:M,i]
00060 * (sub-diag part of the i-th column of A). Note we assign the Norm the
00061 * same sign as that of A[i,i].
00062 * By construction, (1) does not affect the first (i-1) rows of A. Since
00063 * A[*,1:i-1] is bidiagonal (the result of the i-1 previous steps of
00064 * the bidiag algorithm), transform (1) doesn't affect these i-1 columns
00065 * either as one can easily verify.
00066 * The i-th column of A is transformed as
00067 *   (3)  UP' * A[*,i] = A[*,i] - UPi
00068 * (since UPi'*A[*,i]/beta = 1 by construction of UPi and beta)
00069 * This means effectively zeroing out A[i+1:M,i] (the entire subdiagonal
00070 * of the i-th column of A) and replacing A[i,i] with the -Norm. Thus
00071 * modified A[i,i] is returned by the present function.
00072 * The other (i+1:N) columns of A are transformed as
00073 *       (4)  UP' * A[,j] = A[,j] - UPi * ( UPi' * A[,j] / beta )
00074 * Note, due to (2), only elements of rows i+1:M actually  participate
00075 * in above transforms; the upper i-1 rows of A are not affected.
00076 * As was mentioned earlier,
00077 * (5)  beta = UPi' * A[,i] = (A[i,i] + Norm)*A[i,i] + A[i+1:M,i]*A[i+1:M,i]
00078 *       = ||A[i:M,i]||^2 + Norm*A[i,i] = Norm^2 + Norm*A[i,i]
00079 * (note the sign of the Norm is the same as A[i,i])
00080 * For extra precision, vector UPi (and so is Norm and beta) are scaled,
00081 * which would not affect (4) as easy to see.
00082 *
00083 * To satisfy the definition
00084 *   (6)  .SIG = U' A V
00085 * the result of consecutive transformations (1) over matrix A is accumulated
00086 * in matrix U' (which is initialized to be a unit matrix). At each step,
00087 * U' is left-multiplied by UP' = UP (UP is symmetric by construction,
00088 * see (1)). That is, U is right-multiplied by UP, that is, rows of U are
00089 * transformed similarly to columns of A, see eq. (4). We also keep in mind
00090 * that multiplication by UP at the i-th step does not affect the first i-1
00091 * columns of U.
00092 * Note that the vector UPi doesn't have to be allocated explicitly: its
00093 * first i-1 components are zeros (which we can always imply in computations),
00094 * and the rest of the components (but the UPi[i]) are the same as those
00095 * of A[i:M,i], the subdiagonal of A[,i]. This column, A[,i] is affected only
00096 * trivially as explained above, that is, we don't need to carry this
00097 * transformation explicitly (only A[i,i] is going to be non-trivially
00098 * affected, that is, replaced by -Norm, but we will use sig[i] to store
00099 * the result).
00100 *
00101 */
00102 inline Real SVD::leftHausholder ( Matrix &A, sizet i )
00103 {
00104         ColRef UPi = mtl::columns(A)[i]; // Note that only UPi[i:M] matter
00105         sizet j, k ;
00106         Real            sfactor = 0 ;  // Compute the scaling factor
00107         
00108         for ( k = i ; k < M ; k++ ) 
00109                 sfactor += fabs(UPi[k]);
00110 
00111         if ( sfactor == 0 ) 
00112         {
00113                 // If A[,i] is a null vector, no transform is required
00114                 return 0;
00115         }
00116 
00117         Real  Norm_sqr = 0 ; // Scale UPi (that is, A[,i])
00118 
00119         for ( k = i ; k < M ; k++ ) 
00120         {
00121                 // and compute its norm, Norm^2
00122                 Norm_sqr += sqr(UPi[k] /= sfactor);
00123         }
00124         
00125         Real  new_Aii = sqrt(Norm_sqr); // new_Aii = -Norm, Norm has the
00126         
00127         if ( UPi[i] > 0 ) 
00128                 new_Aii = - new_Aii ; // same sign as Aii (that is, UPi[i])
00129         
00130         const Real beta = - UPi[i] * new_Aii + Norm_sqr ;
00131         
00132         UPi[i] -= new_Aii ; // UPi[i] = A[i,i] - (-Norm)
00133         for ( j = i + 1 ; j < N ; j++ ) // Transform i+1:N columns of A
00134         {
00135                 Real    factor = 0 ;
00136                 for ( k = i ; k < M ; k++ ) 
00137                         factor += UPi[k] * A(k,j); // Compute UPi' * A[,j]
00138 
00139                 factor /= beta ;
00140                 for ( k = i ; k < M ; k++ ) 
00141                         A(k,j) -= UPi[k] * factor ;
00142         }
00143 
00144         for ( j = 0 ; j < M ; j++ ) // Accumulate the transform in U
00145         {
00146                 Real            factor = 0 ;
00147                 for ( k = i ; k < M ; k++ ) 
00148                         factor += UPi[k] * UMat(j,k); // Compute  U[j,] * UPi
00149 
00150                 factor /= beta ;
00151                 for ( k = i ; k < M ; k++ ) 
00152                         UMat(j,k) -= UPi[k] * factor ;
00153         }
00154         return new_Aii * sfactor ; // Scale new Aii back (our new Sig[i])
00155 }
00156 
00157 /*
00158 *                       Right Hausholder Transformations
00159 *
00160 * Zero out i+2:N elements of a row A[i,] of matrix A by right
00161 * multiplication (A * VP) with a matrix VP
00162 *   (1)  VP = E - VPi * VPi' / beta
00163 *
00164 * where a vector-column .VPi is as follows
00165 *   (2)  VPi = [ i zeros, A[i,i+1] + Norm, vector A[i,i+2:N] ]
00166 * where beta = A[i,] * VPi and Norm is the norm of a vector A[i,i+1:N]
00167 * (right-diag part of the i-th row of A). Note we assign the Norm the
00168 * same sign as that of A[i,i+1].
00169 * By construction, (1) does not affect the first i columns of A. Since
00170 * A[1:i-1,] is bidiagonal (the result of the previous steps of
00171 * the bidiag algorithm), transform (1) doesn't affect these i-1 rows
00172 * either as one can easily verify.
00173 * The i-th row of A is transformed as
00174 *  (3)  A[i,*] * VP = A[i,*] - VPi'
00175 * (since A[i,*]*VPi/beta = 1 by construction of VPi and beta)
00176 * This means effectively zeroing out A[i,i+2:N] (the entire right super-
00177 * diagonal of the i-th row of A, but ONE superdiag element) and replacing
00178 * A[i,i+1] with - Norm. Thus modified A[i,i+1] is returned as the result of
00179 * the present function.
00180 * The other (i+1:M) rows of A are transformed as
00181 *       (4)  A[j,] * VP = A[j,] - VPi' * ( A[j,] * VPi / beta )
00182 * Note, due to (2), only elements of columns i+1:N actually  participate
00183 * in above transforms; the left i columns of A are not affected.
00184 * As was mentioned earlier,
00185 * (5)  beta = A[i,] * VPi = (A[i,i+1] + Norm)*A[i,i+1]
00186 *                          + A[i,i+2:N]*A[i,i+2:N]
00187 *       = ||A[i,i+1:N]||^2 + Norm*A[i,i+1] = Norm^2 + Norm*A[i,i+1]
00188 * (note the sign of the Norm is the same as A[i,i+1])
00189 * For extra precision, vector VPi (and so is Norm and beta) are scaled,
00190 * which would not affect (4) as easy to see.
00191 *
00192 * The result of consecutive transformations (1) over matrix A is accumulated
00193 * in matrix V (which is initialized to be a unit matrix). At each step,
00194 * V is right-multiplied by VP. That is, rows of V are transformed similarly
00195 * to rows of A, see eq. (4). We also keep in mind that multiplication by
00196 * VP at the i-th step does not affect the first i rows of V.
00197 * Note that vector VPi doesn't have to be allocated explicitly: its
00198 * first i components are zeros (which we can always imply in computations),
00199 * and the rest of the components (but the VPi[i+1]) are the same as those
00200 * of A[i,i+1:N], the superdiagonal of A[i,]. This row, A[i,] is affected
00201 * only trivially as explained above, that is, we don't need to carry this
00202 * transformation explicitly (only A[i,i+1] is going to be non-trivially
00203 * affected, that is, replaced by -Norm, but we will use super_diag[i+1] to
00204 * store the result).
00205 *
00206 */
00207 inline Real SVD::rightHausholder ( Matrix &A, sizet i )
00208 {
00209         RowRef VPi = rows(A)[i];  // Note only VPi[i+1:N] matter
00210         sizet j, k ;
00211         Real                    sfactor = 0 ;  // Compute the scaling factor
00212         
00213         for ( k = i + 1 ; k < N ; k++ ) 
00214                 sfactor += fabs(VPi[k]);
00215         if ( sfactor == 0 ) 
00216         {
00217                 // If VPi[i,] is a null vector, no
00218                 return 0 ; // transform is required
00219         }
00220         
00221         Real  Norm_sqr = 0 ; // Scale VPi
00222         
00223         for ( k = i + 1 ; k < N ; k++ ) 
00224         {
00225                 // and compute its norm, Norm^2
00226                 Norm_sqr += sqr(VPi[k] /= sfactor);
00227         }
00228         
00229         Real  new_Aii1 = sqrt(Norm_sqr); // new_Aii1 = -Norm, Norm has the
00230         
00231         if ( VPi[i + 1] > 0 ) 
00232         {
00233                 // same sign as
00234                 new_Aii1 = - new_Aii1 ; // Aii1 (that is, VPi[i+1])
00235         }
00236         
00237         const Real beta = - VPi[i + 1] * new_Aii1 + Norm_sqr ;
00238         
00239         VPi[i + 1] -= new_Aii1 ; // VPi[i+1] = A[i,i+1] - (-Norm)
00240         for ( j = i + 1 ; j < M ; j++ ) // Transform i+1:M rows of A
00241         {
00242                 Real            factor = 0 ;
00243                 for ( k = i + 1 ; k < N ; k++ ) 
00244                         factor += VPi[k] * A(j,k); // Compute A[j,] * VPi
00245                 factor /= beta ;
00246                 for ( k = i + 1 ; k < N ; k++ ) 
00247                         A(j,k) -= VPi[k] * factor ;
00248         }
00249         for ( j = 0 ; j < N ; j++ ) // Accumulate the transform in V
00250         {
00251                 Real            factor = 0 ;
00252                 for ( k = i + 1 ; k < N ; k++ ) 
00253                         factor += VPi[k] * VMat(j,k); // Compute  V[j,] * VPi
00254                 factor /= beta ;
00255                 for ( k = i + 1 ; k < N ; k++ ) 
00256                         VMat(j,k) -= VPi[k] * factor ;
00257         }
00258         return new_Aii1 * sfactor ; // Scale new Aii1 back
00259 }
00260 
00261 /*
00262 *------------------------------------------------------------------------
00263 *                         Bidiagonalization
00264 * This nethod turns matrix A into a bidiagonal one. Its N diagonal elements
00265 * are stored in a vector sig, while N-1 superdiagonal elements are stored
00266 * in a vector super_diag(2:N) (with super_diag(1) being always 0).
00267 * Matrices U and V store the record of orthogonal Hausholder
00268 * reflections that were used to convert A to this form. The method
00269 * returns the norm of the resulting bidiagonal matrix, that is, the
00270 * maximal column sum.
00271 */
00272 Real SVD::bidiagonalize ( Vector &super_diag, const Matrix &_A )
00273 {
00274         Real  norm_acc = 0 ;
00275         
00276         super_diag[0] = 0 ; // No superdiag elem above A(1,1)
00277 
00278         Matrix A(_A.nrows(), _A.ncols());
00279         copy(_A, A);
00280         
00281         for ( sizet i = 0 ; i < N ; i++ ) 
00282         {
00283                 const Real  &diagi = sig[i] = leftHausholder(A, i);
00284                 if ( i < (N-1) ) 
00285                         super_diag[i + 1] = rightHausholder(A, i);
00286                 norm_acc = maximum(norm_acc, fabs(diagi) + fabs(super_diag[i]));
00287         }
00288         return norm_acc ;
00289 }
00290 
00291 /*
00292 *------------------------------------------------------------------------
00293 *               QR-diagonalization of a bidiagonal matrix
00294 *
00295 * After bidiagonalization we get a bidiagonal matrix J:
00296 *       (1)  J = U' * A * V
00297 * The present method turns J into a matrix JJ by applying a set of
00298 * orthogonal transforms
00299 *       (2)  JJ = S' * J * T
00300 * Orthogonal matrices S and T are chosen so that JJ were also a
00301 * bidiagonal matrix, but with superdiag elements smaller than those of J.
00302 * We repeat (2) until non-diag elements of JJ become smaller than EPS
00303 * and can be disregarded.
00304 * Matrices S and T are constructed as
00305 *       (3)  S = S1 * S2 * S3 ... Sn, and similarly T
00306 * where Sk and Tk are matrices of simple rotations
00307 *       (4)  Sk[i,j] = i==j ? 1 : 0 for all i>k or i<k-1
00308 *                Sk[k-1,k-1] = cos(Phk),  Sk[k-1,k] = -sin(Phk),
00309 *                SK[k,k-1] = sin(Phk),  Sk[k,k] = cos(Phk), k=2..N
00310 * Matrix Tk is constructed similarly, only with angle Thk rather than Phk.
00311 *
00312 * Thus left multiplication of J by SK' can be spelled out as
00313 *       (5)  (Sk' * J)[i,j] = J[i,j] when i>k or i<k-1,
00314 *                                 [k-1,j] = cos(Phk)*J[k-1,j] + sin(Phk)*J[k,j]
00315 *                                 [k,j] =  -sin(Phk)*J[k-1,j] + cos(Phk)*J[k,j]
00316 * That is, k-1 and k rows of J are replaced by their linear combinations;
00317 * the rest of J is unaffected. Right multiplication of J by Tk similarly
00318 * changes only k-1 and k columns of J.
00319 * Matrix T2 is chosen the way that T2'J'JT2 were a QR-transform with a
00320 * shift. Note that multiplying J by T2 gives rise to a J[2,1] element of
00321 * the product J (which is below the main diagonal). Angle Ph2 is then
00322 * chosen so that multiplication by S2' (which combines 1 and 2 rows of J)
00323 * gets rid of that elemnent. But this will create a [1,3] non-zero element.
00324 * T3 is made to make it disappear, but this leads to [3,2], etc.
00325 * In the end, Sn removes a [N,N-1] element of J and matrix S'JT becomes
00326 * bidiagonal again. However, because of a special choice
00327 * of T2 (QR-algorithm), its non-diag elements are smaller than those of J.
00328 *
00329 * All this process in more detail is described in
00330 *       J.H. Wilkinson, C. Reinsch. Linear algebra - Springer-Verlag, 1971
00331 *
00332 * If during transforms (1), JJ[N-1,N] turns 0, then JJ[N,N] is a singular
00333 * number (possibly with a wrong (that is, negative) sign). This is a
00334 * consequence of Frantsis' Theorem, see the book above. In that case, we can
00335 * eliminate the N-th row and column of JJ and carry out further transforms
00336 * with a smaller matrix. If any other superdiag element of JJ turns 0,
00337 * then JJ effectively falls into two independent matrices. We will process
00338 * them independently (the bottom one first).
00339 *
00340 * Since matrix J is a bidiagonal, it can be stored efficiently. As a matter
00341 * of fact, its N diagonal elements are in array Sig, and superdiag elements
00342 * are stored in array super_diag.
00343 */
00344 // Carry out U * S with a rotation matrix
00345 // S (which combines i-th and j-th columns
00346 // of U, i>j)
00347 inline void SVD::rotate ( Matrix &mat, sizet i, sizet j
00348                 , const Real cos_ph, const Real sin_ph )
00349 {
00350         for ( sizet l = 0 ; l < mat.nrows() ; l++ ) 
00351         {
00352                 RowRef Ml = rows(mat)[l];
00353                 const Real  Ujl_was = Ml[j];
00354                 Ml[j] =   cos_ph * Ujl_was + sin_ph * Ml[i] ;
00355                 Ml[i] = - sin_ph * Ujl_was + cos_ph * Ml[i] ;
00356         }
00357 }
00358 
00359 /*
00360 * A diagonal element J[l-1,l-1] turns out 0 at the k-th step of the
00361 * algorithm. That means that one of the original matrix' singular numbers
00362 * shall be zero. In that case, we multiply J by specially selected
00363 * matrices S' of simple rotations to eliminate a superdiag element J[l-1,l].
00364 * After that, matrix J falls into two pieces, which can be dealt with
00365 * in a regular way (the bottom piece first).
00366 * 
00367 * These special S transformations are accumulated into matrix U: since J
00368 * is left-multiplied by S', U would be right-multiplied by S. Transform
00369 * formulas for doing these rotations are similar to (5) above. See the
00370 * book cited above for more details.
00371 */
00372 inline void SVD::ripThrough ( Vector &super_diag, sizet k, sizet l, const Real eps )
00373 {
00374         Real  cos_ph = 0, sin_ph = 1 ; // Accumulate cos,sin of Ph
00375         
00376         // The first step of the loop below
00377         // (when i==l) would eliminate J[l-1,l],
00378         // which is stored in super_diag(l)
00379         // However, it gives rise to J[l-1,l+1]
00380         // and J[l,l+2]
00381         // The following steps eliminate these
00382         // until they fall below
00383         // significance
00384         for ( sizet i = l ; i <= k ; i++ ) {
00385                 const Real      f = sin_ph * super_diag[i];
00386                 super_diag[i] *= cos_ph ;
00387                 if ( f <= eps ) 
00388                         break ; // Current J[l-1,l] became unsignificant
00389                 cos_ph = sig[i];
00390                 sin_ph = - f ; // unnormalized sin/cos
00391                 const Real norm = sig[i] = hypot(cos_ph, sin_ph); // sqrt(sin^2+cos^2)
00392                 cos_ph /= norm, sin_ph /= norm ; // Normalize sin/cos
00393                 rotate(UMat, i, l - 1, cos_ph, sin_ph);
00394         }
00395 }
00396 
00397 // We're about to proceed doing QR-transforms
00398 // on a (bidiag) matrix J[1:k,1:k]. It may happen
00399 // though that the matrix splits (or can be
00400 // split) into two independent pieces. This function
00401 // checks for splitting and returns the lowerbound
00402 // index l of the bottom piece, J[l:k,l:k]
00403 inline SVD::sizet SVD::getSubmatrixToWorkOn ( Vector &super_diag, sizet k, const Real eps )
00404 {
00405         for ( sizet l = k ; l > 0 ; l-- ) 
00406                 if ( fabs(super_diag[l]) <= eps ) 
00407                         return l ; // The breaking point: zero J[l-1,l]
00408                 else if ( fabs(sig[l - 1]) <= eps ) // Diagonal J[l,l] turns out 0
00409                 {
00410                         // meaning J[l-1,l] _can_ be made
00411                         ripThrough(super_diag, k , l, eps); // zero after some rotations
00412                         return l ;
00413                 }
00414         return 0 ; // Deal with J[1:k,1:k] as a whole
00415 }
00416 
00417 // Diagonalize root module
00418 void SVD::diagonalize ( Vector &super_diag, const Real eps )
00419 {
00420         for ( int k = N-1 ; k >= 0 ; k-- ) // QR-iterate upon J[l:k,l:k]
00421         {
00422                 sizet l ;
00423                 while ( l = getSubmatrixToWorkOn(super_diag, k, eps)
00424                         , fabs(super_diag[k]) > eps ) // until superdiag J[k-1,k] becomes 0
00425                 {
00426                         Real  shift ; // Compute a QR-shift from a bottom
00427                         {
00428                                 // corner minor of J[l:k,l:k] order 2
00429                                 Real    Jk2k1 = super_diag[k - 1], // J[k-2,k-1]
00430                                                 Jk1k = super_diag[k] , 
00431                                                 Jk1k1 = sig[k - 1], // J[k-1,k-1]
00432                                                 Jkk = sig[k] , 
00433                                                 Jll = sig[l]; // J[l,l]
00434                                 shift = (Jk1k1 - Jkk) * (Jk1k1 + Jkk) + (Jk2k1 - Jk1k) * 
00435                                                 (Jk2k1 + Jk1k);
00436                                 shift /= 2 * Jk1k * Jk1k1 ;
00437                                 shift += (shift < 0 ? - 1 : 1) * sqrt(shift * shift + 1);
00438                                 shift = ((Jll - Jkk) * (Jll + Jkk) + Jk1k * 
00439                                         (Jk1k1 / shift - Jk1k)) / Jll ;
00440                         }
00441                                                                                         
00442                         // Carry on multiplications by T2, S2, T3...
00443                         Real cos_th = 1, sin_th = 1 ;
00444                         Real Ji1i1 = sig[l];  // J[i-1,i-1] at i=l+1...k
00445                         for ( sizet i = l + 1 ; i <= (sizet)k ; i++ ) 
00446                         {
00447                                 Real    Ji1i = super_diag[i], Jii = sig[i]; // J[i-1,i] and J[i,i]
00448                                 sin_th *= Ji1i ;
00449                                 Ji1i *= cos_th ;
00450                                 cos_th = shift ;
00451                                 Real  norm_f = super_diag[i - 1] = hypot(cos_th, sin_th);
00452                                 cos_th /= norm_f, sin_th /= norm_f ;
00453                                                                                                 
00454                                 // Rotate J[i-1:i,i-1:i] by Ti
00455                                 shift = cos_th * Ji1i1 + sin_th * Ji1i ; // new J[i-1,i-1]
00456                                 Ji1i = - sin_th * Ji1i1 + cos_th * Ji1i ; // J[i-1,i] after rotation
00457                                 const Real      Jii1 = Jii * sin_th ; // Emerged J[i,i-1]
00458                                 Jii *= cos_th ; // new J[i,i]
00459                                 rotate(VMat, i, i - 1, cos_th, sin_th); // Accumulate T rotations in V
00460                                 Real  cos_ph = shift, sin_ph = Jii1 ; // Make Si to get rid of J[i,i-1]
00461                                 sig[i - 1] = norm_f = hypot(cos_ph, sin_ph); // New J[i-1,i-1]
00462                                 if ( norm_f == 0 ) 
00463                                         // If norm =0, rotation angle
00464                                         cos_ph = cos_th, sin_ph = sin_th ; // can be anything now
00465                                 else 
00466                                         cos_ph /= norm_f, sin_ph /= norm_f ;
00467                                                                                                 
00468                                 // Rotate J[i-1:i,i-1:i] by Si
00469                                 shift = cos_ph * Ji1i + sin_ph * Jii ; // New J[i-1,i]
00470                                 Ji1i1 = - sin_ph * Ji1i + cos_ph * Jii ; // New Jii, would carry over
00471 
00472                                 // as J[i-1,i-1] for next i
00473                                 rotate(UMat, i, i - 1, cos_ph, sin_ph); // Accumulate S rotations in U
00474                                                                                                 
00475                                 // Jii1 disappears, sin_th would
00476                                 cos_th = cos_ph, sin_th = sin_ph ; // carry over a (scaled) J[i-1,i+1]
00477                                 // to eliminate on the next i, cos_th
00478                                 // would carry over a scaled J[i,i+1]
00479                         }
00480                         super_diag[l] = 0 ; // Supposed to be eliminated by now
00481                         super_diag[k] = shift ;
00482                         sig[k] = Ji1i1 ;
00483                 } // --- end-of-QR-iterations
00484                 if ( sig[k] < 0 ) // Correct the sign of the sing number
00485                 {
00486                         sig[k] = - sig[k];
00487                         for ( sizet j = 0 ; j < VMat.nrows() ; j++ ) 
00488                                 VMat(j, k) = - VMat(j, k);
00489                 }                                                  
00490         }
00491 }
00492 
00493 /*
00494 *------------------------------------------------------------------------
00495 *                               The root Module
00496 */
00497 SVD::SVD ( const Matrix &A )
00498         : M(A.nrows()),  N(A.ncols()),  UMat(A.nrows(), A.nrows())
00499         ,  VMat(A.ncols(), A.ncols()),  sig(A.ncols())
00500 {
00501         Assert(M >= N);
00502 
00503         //eye(UMat);
00504         //eye(VMat);
00505         setIdentity(UMat);
00506         setIdentity(VMat);
00507         
00508         Vector super_diag(N);
00509         const Real      bidiag_norm = bidiagonalize(super_diag, A);
00510         const Real      eps = base::epsilon2 * bidiag_norm ; // Significance threshold !!!
00511 //      const Real      eps = DBL_EPSILON * bidiag_norm ; // Significance threshold
00512 //      const Real      eps = FLT_EPSILON * bidiag_norm ; // Significance threshold
00513         
00514         diagonalize(super_diag, eps);
00515 }
00516 
00517 // sig_max/sig_min
00518 Real SVD::condition ( ) const
00519 {
00520         sizet minInd = min_index(sig);
00521         sizet maxInd = max_index(sig);
00522 
00523         Real min = sig[minInd];
00524         Real max = sig[maxInd];
00525 
00526         if(min / max < 1.0/MAXCONDITION)
00527                 return MAXCONDITION;
00528         else
00529                 return max / min;
00530 }
00531 
00532 void SVD::inv(Matrix &invA) 
00533 {
00534         Assert(invA.nrows() == N);
00535         Assert(invA.ncols() == N);
00536 
00537         // combine the products to form the pseudo inverse solution
00538         Matrix tmpMat(invA.nrows(), invA.ncols());
00539         
00540         copy(VMat, tmpMat);
00541         
00542         // invert the diagonal elements and apply to the invA matrix
00543         for(sizet i=0; i<sig.size(); i++)
00544         {
00545                 Real tmp = sig[i];
00546                 if(fabs(tmp) < MINSINGVALUE)
00547                         tmp = 0.0;
00548                 else
00549                         tmp = 1.0 / tmp;
00550 
00551                 scale( columns(tmpMat)[i] , tmp);
00552         }
00553 
00554         // U^-1 == U^T 
00555         mult(tmpMat, trans(UMat), invA);
00556 }
